marc:datafield.marc:subfield: Emily Hall was daughter of James L.G. Baker and wife of A. Hall, a physician.

Collection consists of copies of wills of Samuel and William Weldon of Halifax County, N.C., dated respectively, 1779 May 16, and 1785 March 4; two letters written in 1837 and 1839 by James L.G. Baker in Florida Territory to his daughter Emily T. Baker; 1841 letter addressed to Emily by her husband A. Hall, a physician; 1843 letter from L.G. Baker to his wife, Mrs. Sarah Anne Baker, in Scotland Neck, also written in the Florida Territory; and a certificate granting William Weldon Hall permission to practice law in North Carolina.
Alexander Hamilton was a Revolutionary War officer and U.S. Secretary of the Treasury under George Washington.

Collection includes a newspaper clipping of a republished letter, 1780, from Hamilton to Elizabeth Schuyler concerning the Benedict Arnold affair and the death of Major John André, and an original letter, 1791, to Abisha Thomas and James Taylor, treasury agents for North Carolina, enquiring whether North Carolina had ever issued its own certificates of indebtedness in lieu of those of the United States.
Lyman Hall was a physician, clergman, and statesman from Savannah, Georgia. He signed the Declaration of Independence as a representative of Georgia.

Papers include a land bounty certificate; a copy of the will of Mary (Osborne) Hall; a warrant, 1784, relating to damages owed to Lyman Hall from James Martin and Thomas Garrett; and an extract from a speech given by Lyman Hall in the Georgia House of Assembly, 1783, about a controversy over the Georgia chief justice and grand jury. The copy of Mary Hall's will includes provisions for the purchase of mourning rings, the manumission of two enslaved people, and for the housing and furnishing of her old and infirm enslaved people.
Edward Hall and Thomas Hall letters,

The Hall family were prominent residents of Tarboro, N.C. Thomas H. Hall (1773-1853; sometimes referred to as Thomas E. Hall) was a physician in Tarboro who also served as U.S. Congressman and as a member of the N.C. State Senate.

Collection consists of two letters. First is a letter to Edward Hall from William R. Davie, concerning a legal case, [1795?], and second is a letter from Thomas H. Hall to the North Carolina land office concerning the issue of a land warrant, 1820.
Rice planter and governor of South Carolina (1804-1806). He was forced to resign from being Secretary of the Navy in 1811.
Papers consist of a land grant, 1806, and a request for a naval appointment, 1811.
Thomas Lloyd Halsey (1751-1838) was a Providence shipping merchant and French consular agent during the American Revolution. He was later American consul in Argentina (1812-1819).

Collection consists of an 1818 agreement between Thomas L. Halsey and Frederick Thiesen concerning Halsey's participation in privateering operations against Spain and other matters; and a letter from Halsey describing distracted business and social conditions in Argentina in 1821.

Collection consists of letters to Caroline Hamblett from her female friends and sisters in New Hampshire, Massachusetts, and Maine. Topics include health and social activities of family and friends; subjects studied and textbooks used; and religious beliefs. One letter contains an account of a female acquaintance suing a man for breach of promise for having refused to marry her after she had given up her business in the belief that he would marry her. Includes a few short essays on such topics as the evils of alcohol; the transience of physical beauty; and the advantages of early rising.

James Hamilton, Jr. was a congressman and governor of South Carolina (1830-1832); he also served as representative of Texas in 1841 and was senator-elect at the time of his death; he drowned following the collision of steamships Galveston and Opelousas in 1857.
Collection consists of routine personal, business, and political correspondence of Hamilton concerning political appointments and several of the enterprises in which he was engaged.
William John Hamilton was attache at British Embassy in Madrid.

Collection consists of letters by Hamilton to family members, describing his stay in Paris and his journey through France to the British embassy in Madrid. Hamilton reported occasionally on the political atmosphere in Madrid. His letters offer detailed description of social and sporting events, including bullfights, balls, and hunts. Among the people mentoned in Hamilton's lettters are Washington Irving and the English painter Sir David Wilkie.
J. W. Hall was a physician in Saint Louis, Missouri; his brother, Thomas L. Hall, lived in Florence, Pike Co., Illinois.

Letters to Thomas L. Hall from his brother, J. W. Hall, a physician in St. Louis, Missouri, commenting for the most part on family matters, but with occasional mention of politics and economic conditions. An 1842 letter mentions Martin Van Buren's visit to Saint Louis, and spoke of the scarcity of money there.

George Ashman Hamill was a physician from Bedford, Pennsylvania; his brother was William Cromwell Hamill (1821-1843), a businessman of Blairsville, Pennsylvania. They were sons of William Hamill, a physician, and his third wife, Rebecca Ashman Hamill. George Ashman Hamill lived in Bedford, Pa., from 1843-1846, and then settled in Martinsburg, Virginia. J. Q. A. Nadenbousch was an administrator for the Hamill estate in 1871.

Collection consists of bills and receipts of George A. Hamill, a physician, and letters to him from his brother, William Cromwell Hamill, dealing for the most part with family and personal matters. Most items were transferred from the Nadenbousch Papers and date from before Hamill's departure for Virginia in 1846. Collection also contains a letter from John B. McDowell of Lewistown, Ill., discussing the Mexican War.

Miscellaneous letters, for the most part from the Civil War, including a copy of the appointment of J.W. Hall as surgeon in the Confederate prison at Salisbury, N.C.; letters relating to the purchase of Confederate bonds; tax in kind blanks, 1865; and a letter, 1862, reporting strong Union sentiment in Knoxville, Tenn.

John A. Halderman (1833-1908), originally from Fayette Co., Kentucky, was a lawyer and judge in Leavenworth Co., Kansas. He served as major general of the northern division of Kansas state troops during the Civil War. He also served as mayor of Leavenworth, and in the Kansas state legislature. In the 1880s, he was stationed as consul-general and minister-resident in Bangkok; he returned to Washington D.C. in the early 1900s and died in Atlantic City, New Jersey.

The collection consists of miscellaneous correspondence, primarily dating from the 1880s while Halderman was in the diplomatic service of the United States. A variety of matters are discussed, but content is largely personal with little mention of Halderman's diplomatic work. Correspondence is comprised of invitations, requests for consort's cards, and introductions. There are a few Civil War letters and an 1857 letter concerning a legal matter. Correspondents include congressmen, authors, and diplomats.
Manufacturer, of Waynmanville, Upson Co., Ga. Hamburger emigrated to the United States from Durkheim, Bavaria, prior to 1857.

Collection consists of business and family correspondence relating to the cotton textile manufacturing and commission mercantile businesses. Businesses represented include Swift, Hamberger & Co., a cotton factory, and George P. Swift & Hamburger, Warehouse and Commission merchants in Columbus. Correspondents include Hamburger's wife, "Toodie," and his partner, George P. Swift, Sr., of Columbus, Ga. Letters describe Hamburger's efforts to establish a mill and cotton manufacturing concern, and of his 1871 trip to Europe where he arranged for insurance for the mill and visited his relatives. There are also two grade reports from Wesleyan Female College, and a photograph.

Collection consists of miscellaneous letters concerning the Civil War, containing one letter from Libbie Hall and several others in which she is mentioned. Two letters were written by J. M. Stroud to his brother and sister. Stroud discourages his sister Sarah from visiting the Army camps, believing them unfit for a lady. He also advised his brother to not enlist, writing that the Army had as many men as it needed. Stroud describes the Battle of Richmond and subsequent retreat of the Army to Washington, and comments that if Sec. of War Stanton had allowed General McClellan enough troops, Richmond would have been captured in 1862.
Henry Hall was a captain in the 8th Connecticut Volunteers, U.S. Army during the Civil War; he was originally from Danbury (Fairfield Co.), Conn., and enlisted in the army in September 1861.

Collection consists of letters from Hall writing home to his family, containing comments on Civil War campaigns and battles in North Carolina and Virginia, conscription and the draft, African American regiments, army life, and equipment and supplies. Hall describes Camp Buckingham (Jamaica, Long Island); the battles of Roanoke and Newburn; marching through North Carolina to Fort Macon; joining the Army of the Potomac; the battles of South Mountain and Antietam; the Union occupations of Suffolk and Portsmouth; his participation in court martials for military criminals; and his fighting during the seige on Petersburg. Hall includes his regiment's favorable opinions of General Burnside and General Grant, and records that the men disliked George McClellan.

Henry Halleck (1815-1872) was born in Utica, New York, and attended West Point. He remained in the army until 1854, when he resigned to be a lawyer; he re-entered the army in 1861 as major-general. He became General-in-Chief of the Union Armies in 1862, and following the war was transferred to the Division of the Pacific and later to the Division of the South in Louisville, Kentucky.

Collection consists of correspondence concerning the break between friends on opposite sides in 1861; rumors of the mental derangement of General William T. Sherman; and a letter, 1863, from General George G. Meade giving his reasons for not attacking the Confederate Army on the Rapidan in September 1863.

Daniel Kirke Hall was a Union officer, 12th Vermont Infantry Regiment during the Civil War. He later served in the Third Brigade of the Third Division of the First Army Corps; the Department of the Gulf (later the Military Division of West Mississippi); the Fourth Brigade, Reserve Corps; and the 13th Army Corps. He was originally from Pittsford (Rutland Co.), Vt. Hall married Mattie A. Wheaton on January 6, 1867, and settled on his family's homestead.

Papers relating to Hall's service in the 12th Vermont Infantry and as a captain and commissary of the Subsistance Department in the U.S. Army. Contains permits to travel, passes, and orders and many items concerning the Subsistence Department including special and general orders pertaining to instructions for rations of food and related supplies. Generals issuing the orders include Elias S. Dennis, Amos B. Eaton, George Francis McGinnis, and Edward R. S. Canby.

Attorney and politician from Maine; was vice president of the United States (1861-1865). He was appointed by Andrew Johnson as collector for the Port of Boston but resigned over disagreements with Johnson about Reconstruction.

Collection contains a letter, 1866, from Hannibal Hamlin to Henry A. Smythe, collector of the Port of New York, asking assistance for a friend. It also contains a blotter stamped "Library of Hannibal Hamlin," attached to a note by H. Borden Clarke, of Old Authors Farm, Ontario, claiming that the blotter was used to correct the Emancipation Proclamation.
Resident of Greensboro, Guilford County, N.C.

Letters to Hamm from members of his family, including a sister, Mary, sister-in-law, Lora, and brother, C. F. Hamm, who settled in Douglass Butler Co., Kansas. Letters relate to personal and family matters and relationships.
A glance at the past and a peep into the future :
Louisville Female College operated from 1853 to 1880 and was affiliated with the Methodist Church.

Holograph commencement address entitled "A Glance at the Past and a Peep into the Future" delivered at Louisville Female College on June 8th, 1871. Hall challenged her fellow students to diligently continue their studies, with "Shall we improve the little learning we have acquired or shall we neglect and bury it? Shall we waste our precious moments in the gay amusements of fashionable society, or cast our books from sight because domestic duties, and social intercourse demand our attention?" Hall warned that studying may help the graduates to avoid possible undefined and threatening "dark futures," as well as the mistakes made by great nations in the past. Acquired as part of the Sallie Bingham Center for Women's History and Culture. (02-114).
Sallie Bingham Center for Women's History and Culture.
Businessman from Hagerstown, Washington Co., Maryland.
Business letters to William H. A. Hamilton from Baltimore; two letters were written by lawyer Richard Hamilton, his brother.

Henry S. Halbert was a historian and author of The Creek War of 1813 and 1814. Halbert served with the Texas Calvary of the Confederate Army, and after the Civil War was a professor of Choctaw and Creek history and culture.

Collection consists of three letters concerning Indian culture, especially the Creek, Shawnee, and Choctaw tribes; and plans to excavate possible ruins that he believes to have been homes of mound builders.
